Always declare local variables with let or const.
Use === instead of == to avoid type coercion and unexpected results.
Functions are first-class objects in JavaScript.
Use arrow functions for concise syntax and to avoid issues with this.
Use template literals to easily create complex strings.
Async/await makes asynchronous code cleaner and easier to read.
Use destructuring to extract values from arrays or objects.
argument object created with any arguments
Variables declared with 'var' are function-scoped or globally-scoped and are hoisted to the top of their scope.
The 'let' keyword declares a block-scoped local variable, optionally initializing it to a value.
The 'const' keyword declares a block-scoped variable that cannot be reassigned.
Arrow functions provide a concise syntax and lexically bind the 'this' value.
Template literals are string literals allowing embedded expressions and multi-line strings.
Promises are objects representing the eventual completion or failure of an asynchronous operation.
Destructuring assignment allows unpacking values from arrays or properties from objects into distinct variables.
The spread syntax allows an iterable such as an array to be expanded where zero or more arguments are expected.
Async functions provide a simpler and cleaner way to handle asynchronous code, using the async and await keywords.
The nullish coalescing operator (??) is a logical operator that returns its right-hand side operand when its left-hand side operand is null or undefined.
Optional chaining (?.) allows you to safely access deeply nested properties of an object without having to check for the existence of each reference in the chain.
An Immediately Invoked Function Expression (IIFE) is a JavaScript function that runs as soon as it is defined.
Closures are functions that have access to the parent scope, even after the parent function has closed.
The 'this' keyword refers to the object it belongs to, and its value can change depending on the context in which it is used.
The Document Object Model (DOM) is a programming interface for HTML and XML documents that represents the page so that programs can change the document structure, style, and content.
The 'addEventListener' method attaches an event handler to the specified element without overwriting existing event handlers.
JavaScript's 'call' method calls a function with a given 'this' value and arguments provided individually.
The 'apply' method calls a function with a given 'this' value, and arguments provided as an array (or an array-like object).
The 'bind' method creates a new function that, when called, has its 'this' keyword set to the provided value.
JavaScript is single-threaded, meaning it has only one call stack and can do one thing at a time.
JavaScript uses lexical scoping, where a variable defined in a parent scope is available to its child scopes.
Hoisting is JavaScript's default behavior of moving declarations to the top of the current scope.
Execution context is the environment in which JavaScript code is executed, consisting of the variable object, scope chain, and 'this'.
The prototype chain is used to build new types of objects based on existing ones.
Type coercion is the automatic or implicit conversion of values from one data type to another.
Closures are functions that remember their lexical scope even when executed outside of that lexical scope.
The event loop is a design pattern used in JavaScript to handle asynchronous operations.
Currying is the process of transforming a function with multiple arguments into a sequence of functions with a single argument.
The module pattern is a design pattern used to create encapsulated code blocks in JavaScript.
Higher-order functions are functions that take other functions as arguments or return them as results.
Callback functions are functions that are passed into other functions as arguments to be executed later.
Promises are used to handle asynchronous operations in JavaScript, providing an alternative to callbacks.
The fetch API provides an interface for fetching resources (including across the network).
The Event Delegation pattern allows us to handle events efficiently by using a single event listener.
Immutable data patterns involve using non-modifying methods that return new instances of data.
The 'this' keyword refers to an object that's set at the creation of a new execution context (function invocation).
The 'new' keyword is used to create an instance of an object that has a constructor function.
A pure function is a function where the return value is only determined by its input values, without observable side effects.
Memoization is an optimization technique used to speed up function calls by caching the results.
The 'call stack' is a stack data structure that stores information about the active subroutines of a computer program.
Generators provide a way of working with sequences of data more efficiently, allowing you to pause and resume code execution within a function.
The Map object holds key-value pairs and remembers the original insertion order of the keys.
The Set object lets you store unique values of any type, whether primitive values or object references.
Symbols are unique and immutable primitive data types and may be used as an object property key.
The Proxy object is used to define custom behavior for fundamental operations (e.g., property lookup, assignment, enumeration, function invocation, etc.).
Reflect is a built-in object that provides methods for interceptable JavaScript operations, similar to the Proxy object.
The 'class' syntax is a syntactic sugar in JavaScript, introducing a way to deal with object-oriented programming with class declarations and class expressions.
Static methods are called without instantiating their class and cannot be called through a class instance.
Inheritance is a way to create a class as a specialized version of one or more classes (JavaScript inheritance uses the 'extends' keyword).
Template tags allow you to parse template literals with a function.
The 'import' statement is used to import bindings which are exported by another module.
The 'export' statement is used to export functions, objects, or primitive values from a module so they can be used by other programs with the import statement.
Custom elements allow web developers to define new HTML tags, extend existing ones, and create reusable web components.
Shadow DOM encapsulates a piece of DOM inside a component, hidden from the rest of the app, to simplify CSS and markup.
Modules are small units of independent, reusable code that is desired to be used as the building blocks in creating applications.
The 'requestAnimationFrame' method tells the browser that you wish to perform an animation and requests that the browser calls a specified function to update an animation before the next repaint.
The 'Intl' object is the namespace for the ECMAScript Internationalization API, which provides language sensitive string comparison, number formatting, and date and time formatting.
Web Workers make it possible to run a script operation in a background thread separate from the main execution thread of a web application.
Service Workers act as proxy servers that sit between web applications, and the browser and network, are event-driven, and can control the web page/site it is associated with.
The 'WeakMap' object is a collection of key/value pairs in which the keys are weakly referenced, meaning they are not prevented from being garbage collected.
The 'WeakSet' object lets you store weakly held objects in a collection.
BigInt is a built-in object that provides a way to represent whole numbers larger than 2^53 - 1, which is the largest number JavaScript can reliably represent with the Number primitive.
The 'Array.from' method creates a new, shallow-copied Array instance from an array-like or iterable object.
The 'Array.prototype.reduce()' method executes a reducer function on each element of the array, resulting in a single output value.
The 'Array.prototype.map()' method creates a new array populated with the results of calling a provided function on every element in the calling array.
The 'Array.prototype.filter()' method creates a new array with all elements that pass the test implemented by the provided function.
The 'Array.prototype.forEach()' method executes a provided function once for each array element.
The 'Array.prototype.find()' method returns the value of the first element in the provided array that satisfies the provided testing function.
The 'Array.prototype.findIndex()' method returns the index of the first element in the array that satisfies the provided testing function.
The 'Array.prototype.some()' method tests whether at least one element in the array passes the test implemented by the provided function.
The 'Array.prototype.every()' method tests whether all elements in the array pass the test implemented by the provided function.
The 'Array.prototype.sort()' method sorts the elements of an array in place and returns the sorted array.
The 'Array.prototype.concat()' method is used to merge two or more arrays. This method does not change the existing arrays, but instead returns a new array.
The 'Array.prototype.slice()' method returns a shallow copy of a portion of an array into a new array object.
The 'Array.prototype.splice()' method changes the contents of an array by removing or replacing existing elements and/or adding new elements in place.
The 'Array.prototype.join()' method creates and returns a new string by concatenating all of the elements in an array, separated by commas or a specified separator string.
The 'Array.prototype.includes()' method determines whether an array includes a certain value among its entries, returning true or false as appropriate.
The 'Array.prototype.flat()' method creates a new array with all sub-array elements concatenated into it recursively up to the specified depth.
The 'Array.prototype.flatMap()' method first maps each element using a mapping function, then flattens the result into a new array.
The 'Array.isArray()' method determines whether the passed value is an Array.
Error handling in JavaScript uses the try...catch statement to catch exceptions that are thrown in a block of code.
The 'throw' statement allows you to create a custom error.
Custom error types can be created by extending the Error class.
